Comment: So I start with the usual
He replies the same
I do the standard move
He defends his e pawn in a slightly unusual way. Nc6 or Nf6 are more common. This should be playable though.
So I advance in the centre.
This relieves the attack on e5, but at the cost of giving up a bishop for a knight. exd4, Nf6 or Nd7 were better moves
so I take on here. We are actually following a very famous game, Paul Morphy vs Duke Karl / Count Isouard "A Night at the Opera" http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1233404
He has to take the knight, or lose a pawn. If dxe5 instead, I can just exchange queens and then take on e5.
So I take with the queen, developing
He takes back
As played by Paul Morphy
Still following the steps of Morphy

With a double attack on f7 and b7. In the Morphy game, black played Qe7, preparing to meet Qxb7 with Qb4+! and the queens come off. White would have the better ending, a pawn up. Morphy preferred to play Nc3 instead of taking on b7.
This is inferior
Now he loses a rook. If Qc6? to try and hold the rook, Bb5! wins the black queen.
Gameknot post-match computer analysis gives this as a mistake, but black is already lost
So I take the rook
Knight blocks the check
I castle
A mad attack on the king side. Gameknot suggest Bc5 as being better.
